title: Federal Ministry of Finance (Austria)
text:
The Federal Ministry of Finance (, abbreviated as BMF or "Finanzministerium") is the <a href="Federal%20Ministries%20%28Austria%29">cabinet-level ministry</a> for <a href="Finance%20minister">finance</a> in <a href="Austria">Austria</a>. Its seat is at the <a href="Winter%20Palace%20of%20Prince%20Eugene">former city palace</a> of <a href="Prince%20Eugene%20of%20Savoy">Prince Eugene of Savoy</a> in the Austrian capital of <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>. The current Minister is <a href="Magnus%20Brunner">Magnus Brunner</a>.
Structure and function.
The Ministry is responsible for revenue administration at the <a href="federation">federal</a> level, including the <a href="government%20budget">government budget</a>, matters of finance concerning the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>, <a href="tax">tax</a>es, <a href="duty%20%28economics%29">duties</a> and <a href="tariff">tariff</a>s. It defines and conducts the country's <a href="budgetary%20policy">budgetary policy</a> concerning <a href="currency">currency</a>, <a href="Credit%20%28finance%29">credit</a>, <a href="savings%20bank">savings bank</a>s ("<a href="German%20public%20bank">Sparkassen</a>") and <a href="Exchange%20%28organized%20market%29">exchange</a> matters, <a href="Financial%20capital">capital</a> movements and <a href="Settlement%20%28finance%29">settlement</a>, <a href="insurance">insurance</a> control and <a href="hallmark">hallmark</a>s. It is also concerned with <a href="economic%20policy">economic policy</a>, if not discharged by the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Economy%20%28Austria%29">Ministry of Economy</a>.

History.
A first "Hofkammer" (court chamber) <a href="Steward%20%28office%29">stewardship</a> for the <a href="Archduchy%20of%20Austria">Austrian</a> lands was established in Vienna by Archduke <a href="Ferdinand%20I%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Ferdinand I</a>, in order to balance the deficient <a href="House%20of%20Habsburg">Habsburg</a> budget. Re-established by <a href="Maria%20Theresa">Maria Theresa</a> in 1760, the chamber became the "<a href="Imperial%E2%80%93royal">k.k.</a>" Finance Ministry of the <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austrian Empire</a> upon the <a href="Revolutions%20of%201848%20in%20the%20Austrian%20Empire">Revolutions of 1848</a> and took its seat at the former city palace of Prince Eugene.
After the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Compromise%20of%201867">Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867</a>, the Austrian Finance Minister was only responsible for the <a href="Cisleithania">Cisleithania</a>n crown lands, while for the common financial policy of the <a href="real%20union">real union</a>, a separate <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austro-Hungarian</a> "k.u.k." Finance Ministry was established. After <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, the <a href="First%20Austrian%20Republic">First Austrian Republic</a> implemented a "Staatsamt für Finanzen", which was renamed upon the adoption of the <a href="Constitution%20of%20Austria">Austrian Constitution</a> (B-VG) in 1920.
